step1_details: Use a sterile pad, a folded cloth or your hand if necessary. Apply it firmly over the site.
step1_details2: If possible, wash hands and use latex gloves to avoid infection.
step2_details: Utilize a splint or bandage to restrict movement and mitigate additional harm.
step2_details2: Support the injured limb in a comfortable position to minimize pain and swelling.
step3_details: This helps reduce swelling by allowing gravity to assist with drainage.
step3_details2: Support the injured limb comfortably to sustain elevation, promoting optimal recovery.
step4: Bandage the pad firmly in place without releasing pressure
step4_details: Ensure that the bandage is snug but not so tight that it impedes blood flow.
step4_details2: Continue to apply pressure while bandaging to control bleeding effectively.
step5: Do not remove an embedded foreign body
step5_details2: Bandage using criss-cross method to avoid pressure on the object.
step6_details: Without removing the first pad, apply a fresh one and bandage with firm pressure.
step6_details2: Make sure the bandage is directly over the bleeding site.
step7_details: Advise the casualty to remain still and lie down. Staying calm can help slow bleeding.
step8: If excessive bleeding persists, make a tourniquet
step8_details: You can use a belt or a cotton shirt. Apply the tourniquet between the heart and injury, then use a rod or stick to tighten the knot.
step8_details2: Tourniquets are a last resort only.
step9_details: Provide accurate details of the situation and follow their instructions closely.
step9_details2: Stay with the injured person until help arrives, offering reassurance and support.

step1_details: Never use abdominal thrusts on an infant. Lay them face down on your thigh and give up to five back blows.
step1_details2: If choking persists, turn the infant on their back, place two fingers on the sternum and push downwards.
step2_details: Lean the casualty forward and give up to five back blows between the shoulder blades.
step2_details2: If choking persists, stand behind the casualty and link your hands below their rib cage. With your fist, pull sharply inwards and upwards.
step3_details: Link your hands below your rib cage. With your fist, pull sharply inwards and upwards.
step3_details2: If you are pregnant, you should place your hands higher, under the breast bone.

step1_details: Remove any hazards or obstacles like furniture.
step1_details2: Place something soft under the victim's head.
step2: Stay with victim and loosen any clothing
step2_details2: Time the seizure. How long does it last? If multiple seizures, how much time between them?
step3: After seizure, put victim in Recovery Position
step3_details2: Cover the victim with a coat or blanket in case of loss of bladder or bowel control.
step5_details: Check if their airways are clear and monitor any skin changes.
step5_details2: Check their pulse at the wrist. Is it fast or slow, strong or weak, regular or irregular?
step6_details: If seizure is unexpected or different in type, time or frequency seek medical advice immediately.

step1: Risk assessment of victim and area
step1_details: Avoid harm from an agitated victim, bodily fluids or drug paraphernelia.
step1_details2: If you become contaminated wash the affected area thoroughly with soap and water.
step2_details: Be prepared for unpredictable or agitated victims.
step2_details2: If the victim is uncounscious, place in Recovery Position. If they are not breathing, begin CPR.
step4_details: Ask the victim or any bystanders what was taken, how much, how and when.
step4_details2: Keep any labelled items, bottles or containers.
step5: Monitor vital signs every few minutes for deterioration
step5_details: Check if their airways are clear and monitor any skin changes.
step5_details2: Check their pulse at the wrist. Is it fast or slow, strong or weak, regular or irregular?
step6: Maintain the victim's normal body temperature
step6_details: Use foil blanket, coat or blanket to avoid heat loss.
step6_details2: In cold conditions, insulate the victim from any cold surfaces.
step7: Safely dispose of drugs and drug paraphernelia

step1: Remove the victim from any further danger
step2: Cool area under running tepid water for 20min
step3: Carefully remove any tight accessories or burnt clothing
step4: Do not remove any clothing attached to skin
step5: Apply sterile dressing and light bandage
step5_details: Apply a sterile non-adherent dressing to protect the wound.
step5_details2: Make sure to wrap it loosely to accomodate for any swelling.
step7: Do not use any ointments or ice

step1_details2: If not possible, remove victim from the power source using a non-conductive object like a wooden broom handle or a shirt.
step4: Cool burns with tepid running water for 20min
step5: Carefully remove any tight watches, jewelry or accessories
step6: Apply sterile dressing and light bandage
step6_details: Apply a sterile non-adherent dressing to protect the wound.
step6_details2: Make sure to wrap it loosely to accomodate for any swelling.

step1_details: Check the victim's face–does the mouth droop? Can the victim lift both arms?
step1_details2: Is speech slurred/confused? Can the victim understand you?
step2_details: If unconscious and not breathing begin CPR immediately.
step2_details2: If unconscious but breathing, place in the Recovery Position with the affected side down.
step3_details: Check if their airways are clear and monitor any skin changes.
step3_details2: Check their pulse at the wrist. Is it fast or slow, strong or weak, regular or irregular?

step1: Assist the victim to become more comfortable
step1_details: Rest can help slow the onset of a serious allergic reaction.
step1_details2: The victim may want to sit up if they are having difficulty breathing. The victim may wish to lie down if dizzy.
step2_details: Medication may be in the form of a tablet, puffer spray or injection.
step2_details2: Assist victim to find and use their medicine. Hold any injector in place against the thigh for 3 seconds.
step3: If the reaction is caused by a chemical or liquid
step3_details: Wash the contact area thoroughly with running water.
step3_details2: Give an ice cube to suck and place a wrapped ice pack around the throat to slow swelling.
step4_details: Check if their airways are clear and monitor any skin changes.
step4_details2: Check their pulse at the wrist. Is it fast or slow, strong or weak, regular or irregular?

step1_details: Immobilize victim. Apply pressure bandage and splint. Leave fingertips or toes visible to check circulation.
step1_details2: Bring transport to victim. Do not allow victim to move.
step2_details: Apply a wrapped ice pack every 20min. Elevate the limb. Over the counter pain relief can help.
step2_details2: If victim collapses, experiences severe pain or is a young child Call Emergency Services.
step3_details: Douse with sea water or vinegar for 30 seconds. Do not use fresh water. Carefully remove any tentacles with tweezers.
step3_details2: Apply an ice pack every 30min. Call for help and monitor the victim.
step4_details: Brush off bee or wasp bard. Wash with soap and water, apply an ice pack and elevate the limb.
step4_details2: If the victim has a known allergy assist with perscribed medicine. Hold any injector in place against the thigh for 3 seconds.

step1_details: Clean up poison. If swallowed, wash out victim's mouth with water. Do not encourage forceful vomiting.
step1_details2: If inhaled, move to fresh air. If eyes are affected flush with saline or cold water for 15min.
step2_details: Wear a medical mask and gloves. Turn the victim on the side and open airways.
step2_details2: If victim is not breathing, begin CPR and Call Emergency Services.

step1_details: Apply a sterile dressing on any wounds and bandage it in place.
step1_details2: If victim consents, take a photo of the injury prior to bandaging.
step2: Immobilize and support the injured limb
step2_details: Apply a splint and use conforming bandage to inhibit any movement.
step2_details2: Leave fingers or toes exposed to monitor circulation, colour, warmth and pulse in limb.
step3_details: Reassure the victim and tell them to remain still. Remove any jewelry from injured limb.
step3_details2: Use blankets, pillows or clothing for comfort and support. Provide weather protection as required.
step4_details: Check if their airways are clear and monitor any skin changes.
step4_details2: Check their pulse at the wrist. Is it fast or slow, strong or weak, regular or irregular?

step1_details: Before approaching, you must ensure the safety of yourself, the victim and bystanders.
step2_details: Check if the victim is conscious.
step2_details2: Give a shouted command and a firm squeeze of the shoulders.
step3_details: Check that the mouth is clear. Open the airway with a head tilt and with a chin lift.
step3_details2: Look, listen and feel for irregularities with their breathing.
step4_details: Find where the ribs meet in the center of the chest
step4_details2: Place one hand above that point, with heel of hand on breast bone and fingers across chest.
step5_details: Position yourself with your knees close to the victim, your shoulders above the sternum and with straight arms.
step5_details2: Push to 1/3 chest depth allowing for chest recoil.
step6_details: Tilt head back and support the jaw with a chin lift.
step6_details2: Seal nose and give 2 rescue breaths until victim's chest rises.
step7: If possible, use Automated External Defibrillator
step9: Continue CPR until help arrives or breathing resumes
